conclusion: Determine the temperature of the gas in state B using the ideal gas law.
Identify initial conditions at state A: Temperature 27°C, Volume 6x10^-3 m^3, Pressure 1.0x10^5 Pa.
Convert temperature from Celsius to Kelvin: 27°C = 300 K.
Use the ideal gas law PV = nRT for state A.
Rearrange the ideal gas law to find n: n = P_A V_A / (R T_A).
Calculate the number of moles n: n = (1.0x10^5 Pa)(6x10^-3 m^3) / (8.314 J/(mol·K))(300 K).
From the graph, note pressure at state B is 2.0x10^5 Pa and volume is 3x10^-3 m^3.
Use the ideal gas law for state B: P_B V_B = n R T_B.
Plug in known values for state B: (2.0x10^5 Pa)(3x10^-3 m^3) = (0.238 mol)(8.314 J/(mol·K)) T_B.
Solve for T_B: T_B = 600 Pa·m^3 / 1.978 J/K ≈ 304.1 K.
Convert temperature back to Celsius: T_B (°C) = 304.1 K - 273.15 K ≈ 30.95°C.
The temperature of the gas in state B is approximately 30.95°C.
